overview_of_class:
The Post-Self Artist
The individual has travelled the same path blazed over 50 years ago by the minimalist object, with its lack of internal relations and its emphasis on how it works with things around it. Today, along with art objects, art subjects are exteriorized. Having evacuated its core and essence, the individual is now performative, on-demand and just-in-time, in constant feedback with her or his specific context from one moment to the next. From object-oriented ontology to theorizations of information, this class will explore how the centered subject has been displaced. And we'll look at the consequences for the "self" ? as it transforms performatively and communicationally into the agent, operator, avatar, professional and manager, someone who, according to Jean Baudrillard, has given up dramaturgical and symbolic identifications for "organizational values," who privileges relationships "no longer of an instinctive or a psychological but, rather, of a tactical kind," who imagines itself reigning "at the controls of a hypothetical machine, isolated in a position of perfect and remote sovereignty, at an infinite distance from his original universe; that is to say, in the same position as an astronaut in his bubble ... in orbit, living no longer as an actor or a dramaturge but as a terminal of multiple networks."

Pre-Requisite: Art 272 or one 300-level course in the department or permission of intstructor.
